title: Provides a suite of useful tools from the Data Lab ICMAN
text: Show Unicode symbols:
code: library(datalabR) show_symbol_legend() #>  #> --- Package Console Symbol Legend --- #>  #> STATUS MESSAGES: #>  ‚úÖ Success/Approved: Task completed successfully. #>  ‚ùå Error/Failure: Task could not be completed due to an issue. #>  ‚ö†Ô∏è Warning: Task completed, but with potential issues or anomalies. #>  ‚õîÔ∏è Forbidden/Stopped: Action is not valid or has been restricted. #>  #> PROGRESS & ACTIONS: #>  ‚öôÔ∏è Configuration/Setup: Starting a configuration or pre-processing step. #>  üöÄ Rocket Launch/Quick Start: Initiating a critical process or deployment. #>  ‚è≥ In Progress/Waiting: Task is currently running and may take time. #>  ‚åõÔ∏è Time Completed: The waiting period or process has finished. #>  üîç Search/Investigation: Executing a query or data exploration function. #>  üìÅ Directory/File: Creating or accessing a file path/folder. #>  üíæ Save/Write: Data has been successfully written to disk. #>  #> INFORMATIONAL: #>  ‚ÑπÔ∏è Information: General informational or debugging message. #>  üí° Hint/Idea: A useful tip or additional note for the user. #>  üéâ Celebration: Milestone reached or installation complete! #>  #> --------------------------------------

what: Create a multi-bar progress display ‚Äî MultiProgressBar
title: Create a multi-bar progress display ‚Äî MultiProgressBar
text: Manage multiple progress bars simultaneously, useful tracking parallel operations multiple stages process. bar can style format.

text: bars List progress bars

title: Create a multi-bar progress display ‚Äî MultiProgressBar
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Track multiple operations mb <- MultiProgressBar$new()  # Add bars for different tasks pb1 <- mb$add_bar(   id = "download",   total = 100,   format = "{spin} Download {bar} {percent}",   style = "modern" )  pb2 <- mb$add_bar(   id = "process",   total = 50,   format = "{spin} Process  {bar} {percent}",   style = "elegant" )  pb3 <- mb$add_bar(   id = "upload",   total = 80,   format = "{spin} Upload   {bar} {percent}",   style = "blocks" )  # Simulate work for (i in 1:100) {   if (i <= 100) pb1$tick()   if (i <= 50) pb2$tick()   if (i <= 80) pb3$tick()   Sys.sleep(0.02) }  mb$terminate_all() } # }

what: Progress bar class with colored Unicode symbols ‚Äî ProgressBar
title: Progress bar class with colored Unicode symbols ‚Äî ProgressBar
text: comprehensive visually appealing progress bar implementation colored Unicode symbols, spinners, rich formatting options. Inspired cli package standalone fully self-contained.

title: Progress bar class with colored Unicode symbols ‚Äî ProgressBar
text: progress bar system provides: Beautiful Unicode box-drawing characters symbols ANSI color support automatic terminal detection Multiple built-styles (modern, classic, elegant, minimal, dots, arrows) Customizable colors complete, current, incomplete sections Animated spinners various styles Automatic ETA rate calculations Terminal width detection responsive layout Clean completion interruption handling

title: Progress bar class with colored Unicode symbols ‚Äî ProgressBar
text: following tokens can used format string: {bar} - progress bar colored symbols {current} - Current iteration number {total} - Total number iterations {percent} - Percentage complete (e.g., "45%") {elapsed} - Time elapsed since start {eta} - Estimated time completion {rate} - Iterations per second {spin} - Animated spinning indicator {status} - Custom status message custom token passed via tokens parameter

title: Progress bar class with colored Unicode symbols ‚Äî ProgressBar
text: Colors automatically enabled terminal supports ANSI colors. can force enable/disable colors use_colors parameter. Available colors: black, red, green, yellow, blue, magenta, cyan, white, bright variants (e.g., "bright_green").

title: Progress bar class with colored Unicode symbols ‚Äî ProgressBar
text: modern - Colorful boxes smooth gradients (default) classic - Traditional equal signs dashes elegant - Unicode block elements subtle colors minimal - Simple dots, clean fast dots - Circular dots fill arrows - Arrow symbols pointing right blocks - Solid shaded Unicode blocks circles - Circular progress indicators

title: Progress bar class with colored Unicode symbols ‚Äî ProgressBar
text: total Total number ticks current Current tick count width Width progress bar format Format string display clear Whether clear progress bar completion show_after Show progress bar many seconds style Visual style progress bar

title: Progress bar class with colored Unicode symbols ‚Äî ProgressBar
text: ProgressBar$new() ProgressBar$tick() ProgressBar$update() ProgressBar$terminate() ProgressBar$ratio() ProgressBar$elapsed() ProgressBar$set_style() ProgressBar$clone()

title: Progress bar class with colored Unicode symbols ‚Äî ProgressBar
text: Create new progress bar colored Unicode symbols

title: Progress bar class with colored Unicode symbols ‚Äî ProgressBar
code: ProgressBar$new(   total = 100,   format = "{bar} {percent} {eta}",   width = NULL,   style = "modern",   complete_color = "green",   current_color = "yellow",   incomplete_color = "white",   current = 0,   clear = TRUE,   show_after = 0.2,   use_colors = NULL,   force = FALSE,   stream = stderr() )

title: Progress bar class with colored Unicode symbols ‚Äî ProgressBar
text: total Total number iterations format Format string tokens (default: "bar percent eta") width Width progress bar characters (default: auto-detect) style Visual style: "modern", "classic", "elegant", "minimal", "dots", "arrows", "blocks", "circles" (default: "modern") complete_color Color completed portion (default: "green") current_color Color current position indicator (default: "yellow") incomplete_color Color incomplete portion (default: "white") current Starting position (default: 0) clear Clear bar completion (default: TRUE) show_after Delay seconds showing (default: 0.2) use_colors Force enable/disable colors (default: auto-detect) force Force display non-interactive sessions (default: FALSE) stream Output stream (default: stderr())

what: Create a .bib File from an Excel Sheet with DOI-Based Unique Keys ‚Äî create_bib_file_from_excel
title: Create a .bib File from an Excel Sheet with DOI-Based Unique Keys ‚Äî create_bib_file_from_excel
text: function reads list DOIs Excel file, fetches BibTeX entries, rewrites citation key entry sanitized version DOI. guarantees every key unique traceable.

title: Create a .bib File from an Excel Sheet with DOI-Based Unique Keys ‚Äî create_bib_file_from_excel
Create a .bib File from an Excel Sheet with DOI-Based Unique Keys ‚Äî create_bib_file_from_excel
text: excel_path string path .xlsx .xls file. doi_column_name string exact name column containing DOIs. output_bib_path string desired file path output .bib file (e.g., "references.bib").

title: Create a .bib File from an Excel Sheet with DOI-Based Unique Keys ‚Äî create_bib_file_from_excel
text: function return value prints messages console writes .bib file specified path.

title: Create a .bib File from an Excel Sheet with DOI-Based Unique Keys ‚Äî create_bib_file_from_excel
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # First, create a dummy Excel file for demonstration if (requireNamespace("writexl", quietly = TRUE)) {   dummy_df <- data.frame(     Title = c("Article One", "Article Two"),     DOI = c("10.1126/science.1172133", "10.1073/pnas.0806414105")   )   writexl::write_xlsx(dummy_df, "my_articles.xlsx")    # Now, run the function   create_bib_file_from_excel(     excel_path = "my_articles.xlsx",     doi_column_name = "DOI",     output_bib_path = "references.bib"   ) } } # }

text: X vector list iterate FUN Function apply element ... Additional arguments passed FUN .format Format string progress bar .style Visual style progress bar .width Width progress bar .clear Whether clear bar completion .show_after Seconds wait showing bar

title: Apply a function with a colorful progress bar ‚Äî progress_apply
text: list results applying FUN element X

title: Apply a function with a colorful progress bar ‚Äî progress_apply
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Simple example results <- progress_apply(1:20, function(x) {   Sys.sleep(0.1)   x^2 })  # Reading files with progress files <- list.files(pattern = "\\.csv$") data_list <- progress_apply(   files,   read.csv,   .format = "{spin} {bar} {current}/{total} files",   .style = "elegant" )  # Data processing with custom style results <- progress_apply(   1:100,   function(x) {     Sys.sleep(0.02)     rnorm(100, mean = x)   },   .format = "{bar} {percent} | {rate}",   .style = "blocks" )  # Keep progress bar after completion results <- progress_apply(   datasets,   process_data,   .format = "{spin} Processing {bar} {current}/{total}",   .clear = FALSE ) } # }

what: Create a progress bar for loops and iterations ‚Äî progress_bar
title: Create a progress bar for loops and iterations ‚Äî progress_bar
text: convenience function create colorful progress bar Unicode symbols. simple wrapper around ProgressBar$new() sensible defaults.

title: Create a progress bar for loops and iterations ‚Äî progress_bar
Create a progress bar for loops and iterations ‚Äî progress_bar
text: total Total number iterations format Format string tokens (default: "bar percent eta") style Visual style (default: "modern") ... Additional arguments passed ProgressBar$new()

title: Create a progress bar for loops and iterations ‚Äî progress_bar
text: ProgressBar object

title: Create a progress bar for loops and iterations ‚Äî progress_bar
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Simple loop with progress bar pb <- progress_bar(total = 100) for (i in 1:100) {   pb$tick()   Sys.sleep(0.02) }  # Custom style and format pb <- progress_bar(   total = 50,   format = "{spin} Working {bar} {percent}",   style = "elegant" ) for (i in 1:50) {   pb$tick()   Sys.sleep(0.05) }  # With status messages pb <- progress_bar(   total = 30,   format = "{bar} {current}/{total} | {msg}",   style = "circles" ) for (i in 1:30) {   pb$tick(tokens = list(msg = paste("Processing item", i)))   Sys.sleep(0.1) } } # }

title: Iterate over elements with a visual progress bar ‚Äî progress_iterate
Iterate over elements with a visual progress bar ‚Äî progress_iterate
text: x vector list iterate format Format string progress bar style Visual style progress bar ... Additional arguments passed ProgressBar$new()

title: Iterate over elements with a visual progress bar ‚Äî progress_iterate
text: input object progress tracking enabled

title: Iterate over elements with a visual progress bar ‚Äî progress_iterate
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Basic iteration for (i in progress_iterate(1:100)) {   # Your code here   Sys.sleep(0.02) }  # With custom format for (item in progress_iterate(   my_list,   format = "{spin} {bar} {current}/{total}",   style = "elegant" )) {   process(item)   Sys.sleep(0.1) }  # Different styles for (file in progress_iterate(   files,   format = "{bar} {percent} | Processing files",   style = "circles" )) {   data <- read.csv(file)   Sys.sleep(0.05) }  # Arrows style for downloads urls <- c("url1", "url2", "url3") for (url in progress_iterate(urls, style = "arrows")) {   download_file(url) } } # }

Progress bar for parallel operations ‚Äî progress_parallel
text: X vector list iterate FUN Function apply element ... Additional arguments passed FUN .mc.cores Number cores use (Unix-like systems ) .format Format string progress bar .style Visual style progress bar .method Method use: "fork" (Unix) "psock" (Windows/Unix)

title: Progress bar for parallel operations ‚Äî progress_parallel
text: list results applying FUN element X

title: Progress bar for parallel operations ‚Äî progress_parallel
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Parallel processing with progress (Unix-like systems) results <- progress_parallel(   1:100,   function(x) {     Sys.sleep(0.1)     x^2   },   .mc.cores = 4,   .format = "{spin} {bar} {percent} | {current}/{total}",   .style = "modern" )  # Works on all platforms with PSOCK method results <- progress_parallel(   large_dataset,   expensive_function,   .method = "psock",   .mc.cores = 4,   .style = "elegant" ) } # }

title: Show a progress bar for a specific duration ‚Äî progress_sleep

what: A simple custom wrapper to create, configure and tune a workflowr project ‚Äî wflow_datalabr
title: A simple custom wrapper to create, configure and tune a workflowr project ‚Äî wflow_datalabr
text: function automates creation workflowr project. initializes project, configures GitLab/GitHub, creates overwrites specific R Markdown files predefined templates, replaces placeholders, publishes initial site.

title: A simple custom wrapper to create, configure and tune a workflowr project ‚Äî wflow_datalabr
code: wflow_datalabr(   project_name,   existing = FALSE,   username,   creator,   domain = NULL,   repo = c("GitHub", "GitLab"),   attribution,   lic = c("CCBY-NC-SA4.0", "gnu-gpl-v3") )

title: A simple custom wrapper to create, configure and tune a workflowr project ‚Äî wflow_datalabr
text: project_name Character. name project repository. existing Character. Checks package already exists. username Character. username GitLab/GitHub instance. creator Character. name author entity creating project. domain Character. domain GitLab/GitHub instance (e.g., "git.csic.es"). repo Character. type repository commit. Must one c("GitHub", "GitLab") attribution Character. Attribution text license file. lic Character. license apply. Must one "CCBY-NC-SA4.0" (default) "gnu-gpl-v3".

title: A simple custom wrapper to create, configure and tune a workflowr project ‚Äî wflow_datalabr
text: Invisibly returns project path upon successful creation.

title: A simple custom wrapper to create, configure and tune a workflowr project ‚Äî wflow_datalabr
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ wflow_datalabr(   project_name = "my_awesome_project",   username = "Data Lab ICMAN",   creator = "Data Lab ICMAN",   domain = "git.csic.es",   repo = "GitLab",   attribution = "Data Lab ICMAN",   lic = "CCBY-NC-SA4.0" ) } # }
